element.name: 20 A Walk in the Garden-Cleevaun Lough by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/3.5)
element.long-description:
Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE
ON THE LAKE
I drink fresh nourishment, new blood
From out this world more free;
The Nature is so kind and good
That to her breast clasps me!
The billows toss our bark on high,
And with our oars keep time,
While cloudy mountains tow'rd the sky
Before our progress climb.
Say, mine eye, why sink'st thou down?
Golden visions, are ye flown?
Hence, thou dream, tho' golden-twin'd;
Here, too, love and life I find.
Over the waters are blinking
Many a thousand fair star;
Gentle mists are drinking
Round the horizon afar.
Round the shady creek lightly
Morning zephyrs awake,
And the ripen'd fruit brightly
Mirrors itself in the lake.
(Goethe)
On a nice Summer day this would be a good walk in the Garden County with about half of the hike on firm forest tracks and the rest across rough open moorland. The hike of approx 10K should take a little more than 3 hours and has a total ascent of 550m. Please note the red type below and make sure to have all the proper gear. I have shown it as a linear walk in the map above (the easiest and most direct way to get there and back) but there are several ways to make it a circuit if you wish. I would avoid coming back from the Duff Hill direction to the East as returning to the start point from the valley on that side is extremely soggy and tricky.
There are two stages to be found which will provide the exact coordinates for the final cache which is located at Cleevaun Lough. The Lough, one of the highest in Wicklow, is situated in a depression about 250 mtres below the summit of Mullaghcleevaun so there is an opportunity to claim Hezekiah's cache near the summit too as well as his cache on Mullacleevaun East Top.
At the car park you will see a higher and a lower forest track heading in the direction of Stage 1. Take the lower one (on the left as you look). It is a straight forward walk on forest track to find Stage 1 but after passing through a gate (please be sure to close it after you) then turn right up a grass path and through a barrier at N53 08.448 W006 25.354 as this is the only correct route.
Please note that there may be clear signs for sport shooting (presumably deer culling) at certain times of year so please avoid these times which are rare.
At Stage 1 N53 08.131 W006 25.244 (post on the right before reaching the next gate) you will find the last 3 numbers of the first half of the final coordinates. Please take them down in the order they appear and call them ABC.
After making sure to CLOSE the gate, continue along the forest track to Stage 2 at the edge of the forest.
At Stage 2 N53 07.365 W006 24.980 you will find another gate which leads out on to the mountain terrain. Here you will find the end of the second half of the final coordinates close to the gate. Call these DEF
Putting the two together to make up the final coordinates N53 06.ABC W006 24.DEF, you should cross the gate and then a small stream and head across rising mountain terrain in the the direction of Mullacleevaun which is the highest of the mountains in front of you (though not always clearly visible from here).
The going can be soft in the early part of this moorland hike after wet conditions but it improves as you reach higher ground.
Please note that, after you reach and find the cache, you will be returning to this gate (so keep a careful note of the Stage 2 coordinates for your directions) to follow the forest track back to the car park.
From Mountain Views:
Mullaghcleevaun Mountain Wicklow County
Mullach Cliabháin A name in Irish
Height: 849 metres OS 1/50k Mapsheet: 56 for top
Grid Ref: O06763 07049 Latitude: 53.103626 Longitude: -6.406724 ITM: 706688 707081
Joyce says it is named after a cradle-like depression near the top, presumably the one occupied by Cleevaun Lough. Mullaghcleevaun is the second highest mountain in the Dublin/Wicklow area and the 20th highest in Ireland.
Do not start the trek without all the proper mountain rain gear, waterproof boots and the guidance material, compass, map, GPSr with mapping etc. Please note that all parts of this cache are hiked at your own risk. The cache owner takes no responsibility of any sort for any reason including accidents or mishaps.
Please be aware that cars parked in areas close to walking trails are vulnerable and they can be vandalised or stolen. Unfortunately this is an ongoing problem which is extremely difficult to solve. so there is a risk involved.
Please observe the country code to the best of your ability. Local landowners often generously allow access to upland areas across or through parts of their private property. Please, please be conscious of this and return the courtesy by keeping all gates closed, immediately and not on your way back!. Please use the gates where appropriate but if you have to climb over them then use the hinged side ONLY.
Please do not cause any damage of any sort to fences or barriers along the way.
element.additional-waypoints:
B1218BG - Garden 20 Ref Barrier
N 53° 08.448 W 006° 25.354
PK218BG - Garden 20 Parking
N 53° 08.785 W 006° 25.185
S2218BG - Garden 20 Stage 2
N 53° 07.365 W 006° 24.980
element.encoded-hints: Under flatish boulder behind and slightly above large obvious one.
element.url-name: 20 A Walk in the Garden-Cleevaun Lough

ul.li:
2010-04-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by ljeh
My first ever FTF. Really enjoyable walk in the Wicklow Mountains. Thanks for a great cache. The cache is very well thought out and executed.

wpt.name: GC218BG
wpt.desc: 20 A Walk in the Garden-Cleevaun Lough by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/3.5)
